perpetrators: British East India Company legacy policies

mortality.note: Includes Great Famine 1876-78 (5-10M), 1896-97 famine (5M+), 1899-1900 famine (1M+). Grain exports continued during famines. Mike Davis documents this in 'Late Victorian Holocausts'.

rationales.systematic_intensity: Colonial policies prioritized export over food security. Railways moved grain out during famines.
rationales.profit: Cash crop exports continued during famines. Colonial economy extracted wealth systematically.
rationales.ideology: Malthusian and racial theories blamed Indian 'overpopulation' rather than policy.
rationales.complicity: British government, merchants, and consumers benefited. Famine relief deliberately limited.

analysis.pattern_note: Railways built to export grain, not feed Indians. Taxes collected during starvation. Viceroy Lytton held Delhi Durbar feast while millions died. Free market ideology ('don't interfere with markets') used to justify inaction. Parallels with Irish Famine - same empire, same ideology, same result.
analysis.root_causes: Colonial extraction, export-oriented agriculture, racist indifference, economic ideology
